Plot summary performance curves from Zonation output

Source: R/summary_curves.R
summary_curves.Rd

This function reads a Zonation summary curves file and plots one or more summary metrics against the priority rank. The output is a ggplot object, which can be further customized by the user. Optionally, the plot can be saved to disk as a high-quality figure.

Usage

summary_curves(
  data_path,
  metrics,
  facet = FALSE,
  save_path = NULL,
  dpi = 300,
  width = 8,
  height = 6
)

Arguments

data_path

Character. Path to the Zonation output file (summary_curves.csv).

metrics

Character vector. Names of the summary metrics to plot. Metrics can be overlaid only if they share the same units and value range. Fraction-based metrics can be overlaid together, while remaining_area and remaining_cost cannot be overlaid with other metrics.

facet

Logical. If TRUE, metrics are plotted in separate panels. This should be used when plotting metrics with different units or value ranges. Default is FALSE.

save_path

Character. Optional file path to save the plot. The file format is inferred from the file extension (e.g. ".tiff").

dpi

Numeric. Resolution (dots per inch) for saved figures. Default is 300.

width

Numeric. Width of the saved figure in inches. Default is 8.

height

Numeric. Height of the saved figure in inches. Default is 6.

Value

A ggplot object visualizing one or more Zonation summary metrics plotted against priority rank.

Examples

if (FALSE) { # \dontrun{
## Overlaid plot
p <- summary_curves(
  data_path = "path/to/summary_curves.csv",
  metrics = c("mean", "max")
)

p + ggplot2::theme_classic()

## Plot area and cost in separate panels
summary_curves(
  data_path = "path/to/summary_curves.csv",
  metrics = c("remaining_area", "remaining_cost"),
  facet = TRUE
)
} # }
